ArticleInfo.ArticleTitle: Green economy priority sectors in Indonesia: a SAM approach

ArticleCopyright.CopyrightHolderName: Society for Environmental Economics and Policy Studies and Springer Japan

OrgAddress.Street: Jl. Salemba Tengah No. 36-38 Kel. Paseban Kec. Senen

Affiliation.OrgDivision: Graduate Program in Economics, Faculty of Economics and Business

Abstract.Heading: Abstract
Abstract.Para: Green economy has been offered as an innovative initiative to achieve a sustainable development. This framework covers three important aspects, namely economic, environmental, and social aspect. This paper aims to identify sectors that satisfy all three criteria of a green economy framework. Those sectors must have high multiplier effect on the economy, have a relatively low CO2 emissions and better income distribution. Technically, the paper develops Indonesian energy social accounting matrix and calculates three indicators in order to identify green economy priority sectors. Those indicators are output multiplier index, emissions multiplier index, and Theil index. The results suggest 11 sectors that satisfy all three aspects of green economy.

Section1.Heading: Introduction
Section1.Para:
Current economic frameworks that are focusing on economic growth based on natural resources exploitation are no longer appropriate
http://www.unep.org/greeneconomy/AdvisoryServices/Indonesia/tabid/56278/Default.aspx
. Accessed 25 Jan 2012. . The world needs a sustainable economic growth framework that does not cause natural resources depletion and harmless to the environment (UNEP 2011). In response to these issues, United Nations (UN) introduced an innovative initiative which is known as a green economy concept. It is also efficient as one of the solutions to cope with the global economic crisis and market failure (Ocampo 2012).

Green economy is an economic paradigm which promotes low carbon growth, efficient use of natural resources, and equity (UNEP 2011). The main goal of green economy is to achieve sustainable development, which includes three aspects, namely economic, environmental, and social aspect. An implementation of a green economy concept needs additional aspects, such as public supports, policy reforms, and regulation adjustment (UNEP 2011; Blanc 2011). Moreover, green economy can be implemented differently across countries or regions, depending on the strength and weaknesses of a country or region (Chapple 2008).

Green economy framework is in line with the commitment of the Government of Indonesia (GoI) which is formally written in the Medium Term National Development Plan (RPJMN). It is stipulated in Law No. 17 of 2007 (Yusuf 2011) as well as at the UN Summit on Climate Change 2009 in Copenhagen. The GoI has signed a commitment to reduce emissions up to 26 % in 2020 given business-as-usual (BAU) conditions and could reach further 41 % if the program is supported by the international community (Warr and Yusuf 2011). Up to now, Indonesia seems to be far away from its target in terms of the green economy framework. The levels of CO2 emission and depletion of natural resources are still high and above the (world) average level. Figure 1 shows several green economy indicators for Indonesia. Interestingly, several indicators have an increasing trend, such as Gini ratio and emissions level.
Fig. 1
Indonesian green economy indicators. Source: BPS, Pusdatin (2011a, b), WDI database

The United Nations Environment Program (UNEP) argues that several conditions are required in order to achieve a green economy. UNEP (2011) argues that the public investment should be targeted mainly in the green sectors. Consequently, we need to identify sectors that satisfy the green economy concept conditions. Those sectors must have a relatively low CO2 emission, better income distribution and have high multiplier effect on the economy. Partial analysis on sectoral growth, income inequality and CO2 emission have been presented in many previous studies, such as Pal et al. (2012), Pieters (2010), Parikh et al. (2009), James and Khan (1997), Murthy et al. (1997), Ravallion and Datt (1996), and Khan and Thorbecke (1989). However, those literatures did not consider all the three aspects, that is, environmental, economics, and social aspects of green economy. This paper is expected to fill the gap by identifying Indonesian green economy priority sectors.

In general, there are two main contributions of the paper. First, the paper used three indicators in order to identify green economy priority sectors. Those indicators are output multiplier index (OMI), emissions multiplier index (EMI), and Theil index. Second, the paper develops energy social accounting matrix (ESAM). ESAM is a modified Indonesian social accounting matrix (SAM) year 2008 which has a detailed description of the energy sectors as well as households. Households are grouped into 10 groups (deciles) both for rural and urban households. Categorization of households by deciles is conducted in order to calculate Theil index. Similar approach was also used in previous literatures such as Pieters (2010); James and Khan (1997); and Khan and Thorbecke (1989). Disaggregation of the energy sector is essential in order to get information about the level of CO2 emissions due to energy consumption activities. Previous literatures used several method to get CO2 emissions information such as an econometric model (Golley and Meng 2012; Zhang and Cheng 2009; Coondoo and Dinda 2008), Input–output model (Kerkhof et al. 2008; Roca and Serrano 2006; Murthy et al. 1997), and SAM model (Duarte et al. 2012; Pal et al. 2012; Parikh et al. 2009; Duarte et al. 2009; Sanchez-Choliz et al. 2006).

In terms of Indonesia, several studies have been conducted to analyze the link between economic growth, income distribution and CO2 emissions. However, those studies are still partial. Zulfachri (2006); Hidayat (2007) and Hartono (2012) analyzed the link between economic growth and income inequality. Meanwhile, several other studies such as Asri (2010) focussed on the link between economic growth and CO2 emissions. All of these studies did not cover three aspects comprehensively. Thus, this paper is expected to provide useful information for both academics and policy makers regarding green economy priority sectors.

Subsequent to this introductory section, Sect. 2 shows the green economy concept. In Sect. 3, there is an explanation of the data and the methodology. The results are provided in Sect. 4. The final section presents concluding remarks.

Section1.Heading: The green economy concept
Section1.Para: The green economy concept was first introduced by David Pearce, Anil Markandya and Edward Barbier in their book “Blueprint for a green economy” which was published in 1989 (Blanc 2011). They argue that the price system is the main cause of environmental bias in natural resources allocation. Environmental and social aspects are rarely considered in the price system. In some cases the price system does consider environmental and social aspects, but it is still undervalued.

Generally, the green economy concept emphasizes all aspects of the sustainable development framework (Ocampo 2012). UNEP (2011) defines the green economy concept as an economic paradigm that improves welfare, social equity, and environmental degradation. The economy concept will not replace the sustainable development framework. Sustainable development is the main goal in the long-run, whereas the green economy concept is the actions that should be taken in order to achieve sustainability. Sustainable development is commonly presented as a framework that has three elements, namely economy, environment, and social. (Giddings et al. 2002) argue that those three elements are aspects that cannot be separated in the development process.

Several requirements are needed to apply the green economy concept. At national level, government needs to change their fiscal policies, introduce several environmentally friendly regulation, and reform their subsidy policies (for instance from fossil fuel subsidy to renewable energy subsidy). Moreover, government should also increase the public investment on the selected “green” sectors (UNEP 2011).

Section1.Heading: Methodology
Section1.Para:
A social accounting matrix (SAM) is a general equilibrium database which covers production activities, production factors and institutions (Defourny and Thorbecke 1984). A SAM is a square matrix that has two main accounts, namely endogenous accounts and exogenous accounts. Each of these accounts is divided into several sub-accounts. There are three blocks in the endogenous accounts, hence production factors, institutions and production activities. A SAM records the transaction between those accounts in which its row shows income, whereas its column shows expenditure. Furthermore, total value of each account in the row must equal to the corresponding column. Figure 2 shows the basic framework of SAM by using 4 × 4 partition matrix. Sub-matrix
$$T_{ij}$$
T
i j
shows the income of the account in row
$$i$$
i
from the account of column
$$j$$
j
. As an example,
$$T_{21}$$
T 21
represents labor income and profits which is distributed across households, and firms.
$$T_{33}$$
T 33
represents intermediate goods transaction between sectors.
Fig. 2
SAM framework. Source: Hartono and Resosudarmo (2008)

Hartono and Resosudarmo (2008) argue that a SAM is an important analyzing tool because of two reasons. First, multiplier coefficients in a SAM could explain the impact of economic policy on the income distribution. Second, the application of a SAM is relatively simple. Therefore, it can be used to various cases. Furthermore, a SAM is also able to link economic indicators and environment indicators in order to measure the impact of economic activities on environment (Pal et al. 2012).

In order to measure the impact of changes in the exogenous accounts on the endogenous accounts, coefficients of a multiplier matrix in a SAM are calculated. (Defourny and Thorbecke 1984) presented a multiplier matrix in a mathematical expression as: 1
$$y = Ay + x \Leftrightarrow y = \left( {I - A} \right)^{ - 1} x \Leftrightarrow y = M_{a} x,$$
y = A y + x ⇔ y =
I - A
- 1
x ⇔ y =
M a
x ,
where
$$M_{a} = \left( {I - A} \right)^{ - 1}$$
M a
=
I - A
- 1
is an accounting multiplier matrix;
$$y$$
y
is the vector of total income;
$$x$$
x
is the vector whose members are
$$x_{m} = \sum\nolimits_{n} {z_{mn} }$$
x m
=
∑ n
z
m n
; and
$$A$$
A
is the matrix whose members are
$$a_{mn} = {{t_{mn} } \mathord{\left/ {\vphantom {{t_{mn} } {y_{n} }}} \right. \kern-0pt} {y_{n} }}$$
a
m n

t
m n
y n
.

This paper utilizes the coefficients of multiplier matrix to explain the links between sectoral output growth and changes in economic output, income distribution, and CO2 emission. First, output multiplier index (OMI) is used to analyze the links between sectoral output and national output. Second, emission multiplier index (EMI) is calculated to measure the links between sectoral output and CO2 emissions. Here, multiplier is appropriate for indicator since the paper emphasizes the contribution of sector to national output and total CO2 emissions. This approach has been used by several studies, such as Murthy et al. (1997) and Parikh et al. (2009). However, one should consider the impact of sectoral output growth (instead of multiplier) to capture the linkage between sectoral output and income distribution. Therefore, Theil index is used as the third indicator. The approach that is used in this paper is basically similar with Pieters (2010). The distributive effects are analyzed by conducting several scenarios. In each scenario, an injection of exogenous demand by 10 % is applied. The detailed is presented in sect. 3.3.

Output multiplier is one of the methods that are commonly used to analyze the role of particular sector in the economy (Hartono and Resosudarmo 2008; Breisinger et al. 2009; Miller and Blair 2009; Pal et al. 2012). One may also consider several other multipliers such as income multiplier, and value-added multiplier. Based on Breisinger et al. (2009), three types of SAM multipliers (output multiplier, income multiplier and value-added multiplier) are elements of
$$M_{a}$$
M a
. Each of those SAM multipliers has its own application. The output multipliers measure the impact of a shock in exogenous account on gross output of each sector by considering both production and consumption linkages. The value-added multipliers measure the changes in earnings of all labor and capital due to changes in the production in all sectors. The income multipliers measure the changes in the households income as a response to the changes in the earnings of factors. Unlike input–output multiplier, SAM multipliers also consider/calculate the impact of exogenous shock through consumption linkages. Thus, SAM multipliers are normally larger than input–output multipliers (Breisinger et al. 2009).

This study presents output multiplier which is appropriate to measure the linkages between the output of one particular sector and the national output through backward multiplier. In other words, output multiplier measures the contribution of particular sector in fostering output growth of its upstream sectors. It has the same spirit as Pal et al. (2012) and Hartono and Resosudarmo (2008). The SAM output multipliers is used in Pal et al. (2012) to identify a sector which has the largest output growth due to an exogenous shock in Indian economy. Hartono and Resosudarmo (2008) utilized SAM output multiplier to analyze the impact of energy efficiency improvement on Indonesian sectoral output.

Section2.Heading: Output multiplier index (OMI)
Section2.Para:
Output multiplier index (OMI) is used to identify sectors that have large positive impact on output growth. The index is calculated by summing all multiplier coefficients for each sector. Then, the result is divided by total multiplier coefficients in order to construct indexes. Mathematically, OMI of sector j can be written as: 2
$${\text{OMI}}_{j} = \frac{{s\sum\nolimits_{i = 1}^{s} {\alpha_{ij}^{aa} } }}{{\sum\nolimits_{i = 1}^{s} {\sum\nolimits_{j = 1}^{s} {\alpha_{ij}^{aa} } } }},$$
OMI j
=

$$i$$

$$M_{a}$$

); superscript
$$a$$
a
represent production activities block, thus
$$\alpha_{ij}^{aa}$$
α

a a
are elements of
$$M_{a}$$
M a
which only capture the linkages among sector (production activities); and
$$s$$
s
is the total number of production sectors (in this paper we use 41 sectors). An OMI bigger than one means the impact of the growth of a particular sector on national output growth is relatively higher than the average impact of other sectors on national output growth and vice versa.

Section2.Heading: Emission multiplier index (EMI)
Section2.Para: Emission multiplier index (EMI) is used to identify sectors whose growth result a relatively low CO2 emissions. We firstly construct a sectoral emission matrix following two-steps procedure. First, CO2 emissions of each sector is estimated based on CO2 emissions by type of energy database (year 2008), which is published by Data and Information Centre, Ministry of Energy and Natural Resources Republic of Indonesia (Pusdatin 2011a, b). It covers several types of energy, namely coal, gas, gasoline, kerosene, HSDO, LPG, and other refinery products. Total CO2 emissions are proportionally distributed in each sector and institution based on the size of energy consumption. Since there are two prices in the market (subsidized price and non-subsidized price), we first adjust the quantity of energy consumption by using energy prices database.

In the second step, we calculate the coefficients of a sectoral emission matrix (Matrix
$$D$$
D
). Matrix
$$D$$
D
is a diagonal matrix whose members are emissions coefficient (
$$e_{ij}$$
e
i j
). Those coefficients are calculated only for institutions and production sectors. In institutions,
$$e_{ij}$$
e
i j
is the ratio of total CO2 emissions (that is emitted by institution) and total expenditure. In production sectors,
$$e_{ij}$$
e
i j
is the ratio of total CO2 emissions (that is emitted by sector) and total sector output, hence: 3
$$D = \left[ {e_{ij} } \right].$$

After a sectoral emission matrix is constructed, we calculate an emissions multiplier matrix as:

4
$$E = D \cdot M_{a}$$
E = D ·

$$E$$

is an emission multiplier matrix that shows the impact of changes in exogenous account on CO2 emissions;
$$D$$

is a sectoral emission matrix in Eq. (3); and
$$M_{a}$$
M a
is a multiplier matrix account in Eq. (1). Matrix
$$E$$
E
has several blocks, namely emission-sector or emission-activity block, emission-household block, and other blocks that can be used in policy impact analysis (Pal et al. 2012). In this paper, we use emission-sector block since the main focus of analysis is the impact on sectoral output growth. Emission-sector block represents the CO2 emissions which are only generated by the sector activities (excluding households and other blocks).

EMI is calculated by first summing emission multiplier coefficients in the column of sector. Consequently we have an emission multiplier for each sector. Then, we construct an index by dividing an emission multiplier for each sector by the average, hence: 5
$${\text{EMI}}_{j} = \frac{{s\sum\nolimits_{i = 1}^{s} {\beta_{ij} } }}{{\sum\nolimits_{i = 1}^{s} {\sum\nolimits_{j = 1}^{s} {\beta_{ij} } } }}$$

is the total number of production sectors (in this paper we use 41 sectors). An EMI bigger than one means the impact of the development of a particular sector on total CO2 emissions is relatively higher than the average impact of other sectors on CO2 emissions and vice versa.

Section2.Heading: Theil index
Section2.Para:
In order to measure the income inequality, we calculate Theil index based on the procedure that is developed by Akita et al. (1999). In this paper, we calculate two Theil indexes: T 0 and T 1. T 0 is a baseline Theil index (before the simulation), and T 1 is a Theil index after the simulation. In the simulations, we assume 10 % increase in the output of sectors partially. In other words, we run 41 simulations (since we have 41 sectors) and increase the output of a particular sector by 10 % ceteris paribus in each simulation. Mathematically, it can be written as: 6
$$T^{k} = \sum\nolimits_{i} {\sum\nolimits_{j} {\left( {\frac{{Y_{ij}^{k} }}{{Y^{k} }}} \right)\ln \left( {\frac{{{{Y_{ij}^{k} } \mathord{\left/ {\vphantom {{Y_{ij}^{k} } {Y^{k} }}} \right. \kern-0pt} {Y^{k} }}}}{{{{h_{ij} } \mathord{\left/ {\vphantom {{h_{ij} } h}} \right. \kern-0pt} h}}}} \right)} }$$
T k
=

; and
$$h$$

is the total number of households. Changes in the income inequality are measured by comparing two Theil indexes, T 0 and T 1. If T 1 > T 0, the increase of output in a particular sector will widen the income gap and vice versa.

Section2.Heading: Identification of sectors based on green economy criteria
Section2.Para:
Green economy priority sector is defined as a sector that has large positive impact on national output, reduces the income gap and results low CO2 emissions. Table 1 shows categorization of sector based on three indices that are previously explained.
Table 1
Categorization of sectors
Sector categorization
Indices
Green economy priority sector
OMI > 1, EMI < 1 and T 0 > T 1
Satisfying 1 criteria
The driving forces of output growth
OMI > 1, EMI > 1 and T 0 < T 1
Low emissions
OMI < 1, EMI < 1 and T 0 < T 1
Income equality
OMI < 1, EMI > 1 and T 0 > T 1
Satisfying 2 criteria
The driving forces of output growth and low emissions
OMI > 1, EMI < 1 and T 0 < T 1
The driving forces of output growth and income equality
OMI > 1, EMI > 1 and T 0 > T 1
Low emissions and income equality
OMI < 1, EMI < 1 and T 0 > T 1

Section2.Heading: Source of data
Section2.Para:
This paper uses energy social accounting matrix (ESAM) based on Indonesian SAM 2008 which is published by BPS-Statistics Indonesia. ESAM consists of detailed energy sectors and household deciles groups based on income (in urban and rural). The 41 production sectors are presented in Table 2 and the 20 group of households are shown in Table 3. Disaggregation of energy sectors is essential to calculate CO2 emissions due to energy consumption and the introduction of household deciles groups is necessary to measure the impact on income inequality.

Production factors in ESAM are categorized into labor and non-labor. Labor consists of formal labors and informal labors in 4 sector classifications, hence: (1) agriculture workers which cover labors in the agriculture sector, livestock, fishery, forestry, and other related sectors; (2) manual workers which cover labors in mining activities, goods production, construction, maintenance of roads, buildings, machines, including the one who operates the machines or vehicles and other labors who use physical power; (3) clerical workers which cover administration officers, supervisors, accountant, and others; and (4) professional workers which cover legislative members, manager, director, and other labors who use knowledge to solve problems in technology, economy, industry and other aspects (Tables 4, 5).

Section1.Heading: Results and analysis
Section1.Para:
As previously mentioned, green economy priority sectors are identified based on three indicators, namely OMI, EMI and Theil Index. Before the paper presents those sectors, we firstly present each indicator. Figure 3 shows the distribution of OMI for each sector. Four sectors that have the highest OMI are energy-related sectors, namely kerosene sector, gasoline sector, electricity nonhydro sector and HSDO sector. Those sectors have strong linkages with other sectors. Thus, an increase of output in those four sectors will have a positive large impact on national output. Oppositely, three sectors that have the lowest OMI are oil sector, geothermal sector and gas sector (Tables 6, 7).

Figure 4 shows the distribution of EMI for each sector. Based on this indicator, sectors whose growth result the lowest CO2 emissions level are oil sector and geothermal sector. Moreover, both sectors also use inputs from other sectors that emit relatively low CO2 emissions. Oil sector and geothermal sector use gas as it main energy source, and gas has a relatively low CO2 emissions level. Consequently, the direct CO2 emission from both oil sector and geothermal sector are relatively low. In contrast, electricity nonhydro sector is a sector that has the highest CO2 emissions. This result is strongly in line with previous studies, done by Murthy et al. (1997) and Parikh et al. (2009). This paper presents both direct and indirect CO2 emissions by sector, and the detailed is presented in Table 8. The direct CO2 emissions measure the emissions that are directly resulted from energy utilization by a sector in its production process. The indirect CO2 emissions measure the emissions that resulted from the production of intermediary inputs and the emissions by households due to an increase of their income.

Figure 5 shows the distribution of Theil index for each sector. In addition to present the calculation of total Theil index, this paper also present information about the decomposition of Theil index based on location (rural–urban) as well as ‘within and between’ group (see Table 9). Based on this indicator, three sectors that are able to reduce income inequality as output increases are: food crops sector, food, beverages and tobacco sector, and paddy sector. Meanwhile, three sectors that will widen the income gap as its output increase are public services sector, bank and insurance sector, and real estate and business services sector. These findings are interesting since the growth of agricultural sectors and agricultural related industries are relatively able to reduce income inequality. This result is consistent with Pieters (2010), which show that the growth of agricultural sectors will reduce the income inequality in India.

Table 4 summarizes all three indicators by sector. In general, 11 sectors satisfy all three criteria of a green economy concept and ten sectors satisfy two criteria of a green economy concept. Among those ten sectors, public services sector is the sector that can be the driving force of output growth and low emissions. However, as the output of public services sector increase, income inequality will also go up. An increasing output of public services sector will widen income inequality both between regions (from 0.0138 to 0.0140) and within a region (from 0.2186 to 0.2198). Furthermore, income inequality in an urban (from 0.2331 to 0.2349) area is expected to be worse than rural (from 0.1994 to 0.1998). Public services sector such as education, hospital, entertainment center and other public facilities is normally centralized in an urban area. Consequently, a positive growth in public services sector is expected to benefit its workers which are mostly dominated by urban households and widen the income gap.

Trade sector and land transportation sector are grouped as sectors that can be the driving forces of output growth and better income equality. However, the impacts of those two sectors on the environment (based on CO2 emissions that are emitted) are relatively larger than other sectors. Trade sector and land transportation sector use HSDO and gasoline as it main source of energy. As a result, CO2 that is emitted will be relatively high. The third group is sectors that have low CO2 emissions level and ameliorate income inequality. Table 5 shows that there are seven sectors in this group. Those sectors have relatively weak backward linkages. Therefore, an increase of output of those seven sectors will not significantly affect the output of other sectors. Moreover, the technology that is used in those seven sectors is relatively still traditional.

The main focus of the paper is to identify green economy priority sectors based on three indicators. The results suggest 11 sectors that can be categorized as green economy priority sectors in Indonesia. Interestingly 10 out of 11 green economy priority sectors are agriculture-related sectors. These results imply that the agriculture sector still has an important role and proper to be further developed in Indonesia. These findings are strongly supported by Pieters (2010) who suggest the role of agriculture sector to improve income inequality and Ravallion and Datt (1996), Mellor (1999), and Kimenyi (2002) which emphasized the role of the agriculture sector to reduce poverty level. Moreover, Murthy et al. (1997) found that the agriculture sector has a relatively low emissions, both directly and indirectly, compare to other sectors.

The first green economy priority sector is the restaurant and hotel sector. This sector has an output multiplier (not an index) equal to 4.58, means an increase of the restaurant and hotel output by 1 billion Rupiahs will increase Indonesian national output as much as 4.58 billion Rupiahs. At the sectoral level, the largest positive impact will be experienced by the food, beverages and tobacco sector and the livestock sector since the linkages between these two sectors with the restaurant and hotel sector are relatively strong. The restaurant and hotel sector also results a relatively low CO2 direct emissions. This sector emits only 0.28 tons CO2 emissions from its direct consumption of energy (in the production process) out of 85 tons total CO2 emissions in order to produce 1 billion Rupiahs of output. An increase of the output of the restaurant and hotel sector will increase the demand of the food crops products and the livestock products. Consequently, it will increase the demand of labor not only in the restaurant and hotel sector, but also in the food crops sector and the livestock sector. As a result, group of household that will be positively and significantly affected is the bottom deciles rural household group. This household group is expected to have a higher income as much as 1.74 %.
The detailed results are available upon request.

The second green economy priority sector is the livestock sector. The livestock sector has a slightly higher output multiplier relative to the restaurant and hotel sector as much as 4.61. The food, beverages and tobacco sector and the trade sector are two sectors that are strongly related to the livestock sector. An increase of the output of the livestock sector will have a positive impact on income equality particularly on rural households. The oil and fat industry sector is the third green economy priority sector. This sector has an output multiplier as much as 4.52 which is almost similar to the restaurant and hotel sector. One of the strengths of this sector is its ability to improve household income. An increase of the output of the oil and fat sector by 1 billion Rupiahs will increase household income as much as 2.35 billion Rupiahs. The positive impact on income will be dominantly experienced by the bottom deciles household group and will ameliorate income equality.

The fourth green economy priority sector is the food, beverages and tobacco sector. This sector also has an output multiplier larger than 4 and emits CO2 as much as 88 tons. The food, beverages and tobacco sector will have a positive and significant impact on the bottom deciles rural household group particularly through informal agriculture workers. The fifth green economy priority sector is the paddy sector. An increase of the output of the paddy sector by 1 billion Rupiahs will increase Indonesian national output as much as 4.29 billion Rupiahs. At the sectoral level, the most affected sector due to an increase of the paddy sector output is the food, beverages and tobacco sector. In terms of CO2 emissions, the paddy sector has the lowest direct emissions as much as 0.007 tons if the output of the paddy sector increases by 1 billion Rupiahs. Similar with other green economy priority sectors, the paddy sector will have larger positive impact on income equality among rural household relative to urban household.

The other green economy priority sectors are the food crops sector, the rubber sector, the other crops sector and the coconut sector. One billion Rupiahs increase in the output of those sectors will increase Indonesian national output as much as 4.48, 4.36, 4.25 and 4.24 billion Rupiahs, respectively. The impact of those four sectors on CO2 emissions is slightly higher than the previous five sectors by as much as 102, 100, 99 and 100 tons, respectively, if the output of those sectors increase by 1 billion Rupiahs. The main differences between those four sectors are its impact on income inequality. Even though all four sectors will improve income inequality, the impacts are different across household groups. The food crops sector, the other crops sector and the coconut sector will have a larger impact on rural household, whereas the rubber sector will have a larger impact on urban household.

The last two green economy priority sectors are the wood and wood products sector and the other mining and quarries sector. Those two sectors have output multiplier equal to 4.16 and 4.02. It means that 1 billion Rupiahs increase in the output of those two sectors will raise national output approximately 4.16 and 4.02 billion Rupiahs, respectively. Moreover, an increase of the output of the wood and wood products sector will ameliorate income equality particularly among urban household group. Meanwhile, the other mining and quarries sector will have larger positive impact on income equality among rural household group relative to urban household group. In terms of CO2 emissions, those two sectors emit as much as 97.8 and 101 tons CO2, respectively. Indeed we should carefully interpret the results of the paper. As previously mentioned in the methodology, level of CO2 emissions in this paper is measured based on energy consumption both directly and indirectly. It does not cover other aspects such as CO2 which is emitted due to deforestation.

Section1.Heading: Conclusion
Section1.Para: The paper identifies Indonesian green economy priority sectors based on three indicators, using SAM model. There are several limitations to this study: (1) production function is assumed to be linear and follows constant return to scale; (2) the model does not address price issue; (3) technology is assumed to be fixed (fixed Leontief technology); (4) equilibrium in SAM is assumed to be static, even though in reality economic structure seems to be dynamic; (5) it does not address negative externalities; (6) calculation of CO2 emissions level is limited to the consumption of fossil fuels (coal, gasoline, kerosene, HSDO, gas, LPG, and city gas). The paper identifies 11 sectors that satisfy all three criteria of a green economy concept and ten sectors that satisfy two criteria of a green economy concept.

The paper also identifies 11 sectors that satisfy all three criteria of a green economy concept and ten sectors that satisfy two criteria of a green economy concept. Interestingly, most of the green sectors are dominated by agriculture-related sectors. One may argue that those results are weak, due to the limitation of CO2 emissions measurement in this study. Indeed, the calculation of CO2 emission in this paper is limited to fossil fuel consumption, but there are several reasons why this approach is used. First, this paper uses Static SAM. Therefore, it cannot capture the dynamics of changes in land-use.
To the best of author’s knowledge, there is no study that models land-use changes by using SAM in order to calculate CO2 emission from agriculture. However, Warr and Yusuf (2011) introduce a CGE model to analyze the same issue. Second, the increase in the agricultural output should not be translated directly into higher land use. Larger agricultural output can also be achieved through productivity improvement or the utilization of marginal land or degraded land.

There are at least four policy recommendations that can be derived from the results of the study. First, the Government of Indonesia (GoI) should give special attention to Indonesian green economy priority sectors. Several strategies that can be taken are: (1) accelerating agriculture productivity improvement through superior seeds varieties program, credit for farmer, increasing farmer wage, and optimization agriculture cooperatives and farmer groups; (2) developing agriculture-based industries in rural areas that can create new employments for rural households.

Second, sectors that can be the driving force of output growth and improve income equality should be encouraged to participate in CO2 emissions reduction program. Firms or businesses should conduct fuel conversion program from HSDO or gasoline to gas (which has a relatively low CO2 emissions level) and apply energy efficiency improvement program. Third, the GoI should reform public sector since this sector satisfies two criteria but has a potential to widen income inequality. Several strategies that can be taken are: (1) increasing number and the quality of educational facilities (schools), health facilities (hospitals) and other social facilities in rural areas; (2) creating better access to educational facilities, health facilities and other social facilities for poor households. Fourth, productivity improvement program should be applied to sectors that satisfy two criteria but have small output multiplier. Those sectors should adopt better technology and conduct more research and development (R&D) activities.

Section1.Heading: Appendix
Section1.Para: See Tables 7, 8, and 9.
